channel.title: remove-system.map cannot work - `/lib/modules` is mounted read-only
channel.description:
Whonix tries to remove `System.map` file, but isn't possible since the modules are mounted read-only. With dom0-provided kernel (as opposed to a custom local build), it doesn't really make sense, since the file is public anyway (downloadable in kernel package) and identical on all installations (that use the same kernel version).

item.title: remove-system.map cannot work - `/lib/modules` is mounted read-only
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Thank you for the bug report!

A solution for read-only support will be implemented soon. Most likely by skipping any attempt to delete these files.

system.map deletion came originally up here:

Kernel Hardening Development
The System.map files should be removed. By default, /boot/System.map-* contains kernel symbols which could be useful to an attacker. Setting kernel.kptr_restrict=2 hides these from /proc/kallsyms but an attacker can just look at the System.map files to get the symbols anyway. These could possibly be purged during the build or at boot with a systemd service. Tails also removes these. https://redmine.tails.boum.org/code/issues/10951 System.map files are only used for debugging or malware. It â€¦

It makes most sense when using a self-compiled custom kernel but weâ€™re not there yet. Otherwise in theory would only break malware that depends on reading that file without a hardcoded implementation.
